prompt.p: A 58-year-old man on amiodarone for supraventricular tachycardia presents with insomnia, sweating, diarrhoea and palpitations. On examination, there is atrial fibrillation, a tremor and moist skin. Thyroid function tests reveal:
What is the most appropriate management?

modalFeedback.p: Option E (Stop amiodarone) is Correct. Amiodarone has a high concentration of iodine and it has a long half-life. This patient has iodine-induced thyrotoxicosis. Termination of amiodarone is necessary to control his thyrotoxic state. Given the long half-life of amiodarone, he may require carbimazole.
Option A (Aspirin) is Incorrect. This is used to treat de Quervain's thyroiditis. This disease is due to a self-limiting upper respiratory tract infection. It results in a painful thyroid swelling.
Option B (Levothyroxine) is Incorrect. This is used to treat hypothyroidism. The patient has a pulse that is not bradycardic, which is a feature of hypothyroidism.
Option C (Propanolol) is Incorrect. This is used in hyperthyroidism and thyroid crisis. Such a patient would be tachycardic, i.e. have a pulse rate >100 beats/min.

Option D (Radioiodine) is Incorrect. Iodine 131 is used to treat thyrotoxicosis and thyroid carcinoma. Its use may cause thyroiditis. In this patient r adioiodine is not effective due to reduced uptake by the thyroid gland.
